question: Question_02
statement:
A certain random variable \emph{X} takes values in the interval
$0 \leq x \leq 2$, with probability density

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
p(x) = 1-x/2\end{align*} Find the mean and variance of \emph{X}.
sols:
Given the probability density \emph{p(x)=1-x/2} over the interval
$0 \leq x \leq 2$ we plug this into the formula for the mean to get

\begin{align*}
\mu &= \int_{0}^{2}x \left (1-\frac{x}{2} \right)dx \\
&= \int_{0}^{2} \left (x-\frac{x^{2}}{2} \right)dx \\
&=\left [ \frac{x^{2}}{2}-\frac{x^{3}}{6} \right ]_{0}^{2} \\
&=\left ( \frac{2^{2}}{2}-\frac{2^{3}}{6} \right )-\left ( \frac{0^{2}}{2}-\frac{0^{3}}{6}\right ) \\
&= \mathbf{\frac{2}{3}}\end{align*}

Using the first formula for the variance with $\mu=\frac{2}{3}$,

\begin{align*}
V &= \int_{0}^{2}\left(x-\frac{2}{3} \right )^{2} \left(1-\frac{x}{2} \right ) dx \\
&= \int_{0}^{2}\left(x^{2}-\frac{4}{3}x+\frac{4}{9} \right ) \left(1-\frac{x}{2} \right ) dx \\
&= \int_{0}^{2} \left(\frac{-x^{3}}{2}+\frac{5}{3}x^{2}-\frac{14}{9}x+\frac{4}{9} \right )dx \\
&= \left [ -\frac{x^{4}}{8}+\frac{5}{9}x^{3}-\frac{7}{9}x^{2}+\frac{4}{9}x \right ]_{0}^{2} \\
&= \left ( -\frac{2^{4}}{8}+\frac{5}{9}(2)^{3}-\frac{7}{9}(2)^{2}+\frac{4}{9}(2) \right )-\left ( -\frac{0^{4}}{8}+\frac{5}{9}(0)^{3}-\frac{7}{9}(0)^{2}+\frac{4}{9}(0) \right ) \\
&= -\frac{16}{8}+\frac{40}{9}-\frac{28}{9}+\frac{8}{9}-0 = -2+\frac{20}{9} \\
&= \mathbf{\frac{2}{9}}\end{align*}

Alternatively, using the other formula for the variance, we get the same
value:

\begin{align*}
V &= \int_{0}^{2}x^2\left (1-\frac{x}{2} \right )dx-\left( \frac{2}{3} \right )^2 \\
&= \int_{0}^{2}\left (x^2-\frac{x^3}{2} \right )dx-\frac{4}{9} \\
&= \left[\frac{x^3}{3}-\frac{x^4}{8} \right ]_{0}^{2}-\frac{4}{9} \\
&= \left (\frac{2^3}{3}-\frac{2^4}{8} \right ) - \left (\frac{0^3}{3}-\frac{0^4}{8} \right )-\frac{4}{9} = \frac{8}{3}-2-\frac{4}{9} \\
&= \mathbf{\frac{2}{9}}\end{align*}
hints:
For a probability density \emph{p(x)} defined over the interval
$a \leq x \leq b$, the mean value of \emph{X}, denoted by $\mu$, is
given by

\begin{align*}\mu=\int_{a}^{b}xp(x)dx\end{align*}
